headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MARTINEZ, MARK VIATORI
summary: MARTINEZ--Mark Viatori, died peacefully on Thursday January, 23, 2014 surrounded by loving family. He was 41 years old. He was a father, husband, son, brother, friend, accomplished builder, sea captain, big wave surfer, philanthropist, saltwater fisherman, snowboarder, soccer and hockey player. He is survived by his wife, Uli (Ulrike) De Vreese Martinez, his daughters, Juliana De Vreese Martinez, 7, and Esmee Nicolina Martinez, 4, his parents, Antonia Viatori Martinez and Albert A. Martinez, his step-father, Friedrich (Fritz) Pangratz, his sister, the Honorable Stefanie A. Martinez, brother-in-law, Sergeant Steve Garcia, nieces, Isabela Martinez Thibodeau and Sofia Martinez Thibodeau, nephews, Nicolas Martinez and Maximilian Martinez, great-aunt Magali Leiseca, aunts, Maria Ryan, Joanna Martinez, Sister Maria Viatori, OCD, Nancy Anne Viatori, and uncles, Wilfred Martinez, Maximilian Viatori and Robert Ryan. Mark was recognized by colleagues, friends and family members for his honest nature and can-do attitude. There was never an obstacle that Mark didn't meet with a smile and tackle with vigor, determination and grace. His unique style and presence, especially in the face of challenges others would have shied away from, distinguished him as an individual. Doing good by doing right was his way. Mark was defined by generosity and fierce loyalty. Mark invested 100% of himself into everything he committed to - his family, friends, sports and business. Family was paramount for Mark. Mark was a resident of both Manhattan and Southampton, NY. He was born in Rochester, NY on November 7th, 1972. Mark grew up in Rumson, NJ where he attended Rumson Country Day School, Rumson Fair Haven High School and ultimately matriculated to UNC Wilmington, where he was a member of the Chi Phi fraternity. Professionally, Mark built upon the foundation that his father created when he assumed responsibility of Interior Management, Inc (IMI). He had a specific vision for the company, focused on quality workmanship and culture, and has grown the business into Manhattan, the Hamptons, and New Jersey's foremost construction and renovation partner. A Memorial Visitation will be held at Frank E. Campbell at 1076 Madison Ave. Monday January 27th from 4pm-9pm. A Memorial Mass will be held at The Church of St. Ignatius Loyola at 980 Park Ave. on Tuesday January 28th at 4pm. In lieu of flowers the family is requesting donations to Habitat for Humanity.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MUSE, MARTHA TWITCHELL
summary: MUSE--Martha Twitchell. The board and staff of the Tinker Foundation Incorporated mourn the passing of its former Chairman and President, Martha T. Muse. She died on Sunday, February 9th, in Stuart, Florida after a brief illness. Martha was born in Dallas, Texas in 1926, the daughter of John Blackburn Muse and Kathryn Poole Burbank, but lived in New York City for most of her life. She maintained residences in New York City, Connecticut and Florida. Her principal interests focused on Latin America, but she contributed substantially to educational, corporate and non-profit areas. Martha was a founding director of the Tinker Foundation. She served as its president for 27 years and its chairman for 33 years, retiring in 2008. It was under her direction that the Foundation became a leading funder of Latin American-related activities providing support for educational, environmental, security, economic, legal and governance issues. Martha received her undergraduate degree from Barnard College in 1948 and a master's degree in political science from Columbia University in 1955. In 1981 she received an honorary doctorate from Georgetown University. She was the first woman elected as a trustee to Columbia University and was among the first women named to the Board of the New York Stock Exchange and the Council on Foreign Relations. She served on numerous corporate boards including The Bank of New York, May Department Stores, Sterling Drug Inc., ASARCO, ACF Industries and Associated Dry Goods. Her non-profit boards included the Americas Society, the Spanish Institute, and the Luso-American Development Foundation. For her many contributions to the field of Latin American relations she received numerous awards: Orden del Sol del Peru, Order of Bernardo O'Higgins (Chile), Order de Mayo al Merito (Argentina); Ordem Nacional do Cruzeiro do Sul (Brazil), and awards from the Spanish Institute and the Americas Society. She was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations, the Colony Club, the Huguenot Society and the National Society of Colonial Dames. One of her final directives to the Tinker Foundation was incorporating Antarctica-related subjects under its funding mandate. Her support of Antarctica was recognized in 2009 by the establishment of the Muse Prize for Science and Policy in Antarctica, an award for mid-career Antarctic scientists and policy makers. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the late spring. Letters of inquiry and condolence may be sent to the Tinker Foundation, 55 E. 59th St., New York, NY 10022.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BRANDE, RALPH T.
summary: BRANDE--Ralph T.,a long time New York City educator and school leader, passed away on September 22, at the age of 91. Born in Brooklyn to Raphael Aloysius Brande and Laura Marie Brande (Maroselli) on November 24, 1921, he was a graduate of New Utrecht High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia University. Mr. Brande served his country during World War II as a Second Lieutenant in the U.S. Army Air Corps before beginning his career as a teacher and administrator. His marriage to RoseMarie Roubian in 1944 lasted until her death in 1999. Predeceased by his son, William, and brother, Rev. Edward W. Brande, S.J., he remained the loving father to three daughters and three sons. During his 38 years in education, he served as a Social Studies teacher at Midwood High School and Junior High School 57, a supervisor at the Board of Education, principal of the John F. Hylan Elementary School, and from 1968 to 1984 as Community Superintendent in Districts 14 and 22. He was the author of books on American History, reading skills, and school leadership. During his retirement, he served as a consultant to the NYC Board of Education in the training of community superintendents. Recognized by Stanford University for exemplary leadership and by Brooklyn College as a distinguished alumnus, he was one of NYC's most well known and respected school leaders during the 1970s and 80s. He was a long time member of St. Raymond's Roman Catholic Church in East Rockaway and Our Lady, Queen of Martyrs in Centerport. He is survived by his loving second wife, Celeste Pasquariello and her family, daughters Kathryn Killelea (Michael), Bonnie Fortney (Frank), and Jill Hissong (Joseph), sons Richard (Maureen), John (Gay) and Christopher (Alison), 15 grandchildren, and 11 great-grandchildren. The family will receive friends Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Perry Funeral Home, Inc. 118 Union Avenue Lynbrook, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10:45am at St. Raymond's RC Church. Interment to follow at Calverton National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers please make memorial contributions to Long Island Alzheimers.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BISSELL, ELLISTON P.
summary: BISSELL--Elliston Perot III. Pete passed away peacefully on the evening of November 19, 2013 in Chatham, New Jersey. Pete was well known and loved by many and lived a rich and rewarding life. The son of Elliston Perot Bissell, Jr. and Ann Packard Bissell, Pete was born In Jamaica Queens New York on May 26th, 1935. He spent his early years in Morristown, New Jersey and Haverford, Pennsylvania. He attended the Episcopal School in Philadelphia and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire in 1953. Pete attended Harvard College, where he majored in Biochemical Sciences. While at Harvard he was a member of the Hasty Pudding, Lampoon, and President of the Phoenix-S.K. After graduating from Harvard in 1957, Pete joined the US Navy as a junior lieutenant. headline: Paid Notice: Deaths COOKE, ANNE ELIZABETH RYAN
summary: COOKE--Anne Elizabeth Ryan, passed from this world early on Saturday, November 23, 2013; she had been resting at her home in Williamsburg, VA since August. Anne, Senior Vice President of Emblem Health, a New York based Health insurance Company, had been living and working in NYC for a little over a year. After a successful career with AT&T, she retired in 1998 to pursue other interests, including a short period with Michigan Consolidate Gas and Gen Three in Boston. Anne then came to the Healthcare industry with leadership positions at WellPoint, where she was responsible for the rollout of their Medicare Part D product, then DaVita Inc. with their Home Healthcare Division and finally with Emblem Health where she was responsible for Operations and IT. Anne remained in NYC during Hurricane Sandy to help keep Emblem's IT systems operational as power was lost and backups restored. She is survived by her husband of 23 years, Bruce Cooke, daughter, Victoria Cooke, Williamsburg, VA and sisters, Mary Nell Ryan, Milwaukee, WI, and Jeanne Ryan, Duluth, MN. Anne grew up in the suburbs of Milwaukee, was a nationally ranked swimmer in high school, and then attended St. Catherine University, St. Paul, MN, graduating in 1980 with honors and member of Phi Beta Kappa. Anne felt her greatest work satisfaction came in the Health Industry; a colleague who worked with her at Emblem can best describe her in the quote below: "Anne was inspirational, honest, and genuine. In speaking with many other people about Anne they each felt important and full of purpose after meeting her and hearing her vigor for life and dedication to transforming our organization. And she did just that; transform it. She held others accountable and required nothing but the best from each of us. I am a better person and stronger leader because of her. God bless." The family will receive local friends and neighbors on Tuesday evening, November 26th, from 4-7pm at Nelsen Funeral Home, 3785 Strawberry Plains Rd., Williamsburg, VA 23188. A Celebration of Life will be scheduled at a later time. The family is requesting in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice House of Williamsburg, 4445 Powhatan Pkwy, Williamsburg, VA 23188 in honor of Anne Cooke. Online condolences may be offered at www.nelsecares.com.
